content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

The slide displays multiple sections of tissue. The majority appear to be lymph nodes, approximately 10-12 in total, several of which are heavily replaced by purple (basophilic) tissue, suggesting metastatic tumor. There is one particularly large, round tissue piece in the lower left quadrant with a thick pink wall and a necrotic-appearing center. This structure is highly suspicious and could represent either a completely effaced lymph node with extensive necrosis or a cross-section of a large, tumor-invaded blood vessel.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

I am zooming into the wall of the large, suspicious nodule in the lower left. This structure's morphology, with a thick wall and a large lumen filled with necrotic material, is highly suggestive of a large blood vessel. The purpose of this zoom is to investigate for extramural venous invasion (EMVI), which is the presence of tumor within a vein located outside the bowel wall's muscularis propria. Confirming EMVI is critical for staging and has significant prognostic implications. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, I would examine each lymph node systematically. The green box is placed on the first lymph node at the top-left of the image. This is a logical starting point for a methodical review of all the submitted lymph nodes to assess them for the presence of metastasis. I am starting my search for positive lymph nodes here. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, I systematically examine every lymph node to check for the presence of metastasis. The green box is centered on one of the medium-sized, densely cellular lymph nodes (approximately the 4th one down from the top left). At low power, while it is predominantly basophilic, there are subtle hints of architectural disruption and paler areas that are not typical reactive germinal centers. This raises suspicion for an early or partial metastatic infiltrate, which must be confirmed at high magnification. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into this specific area because it represents one of the larger, more cellular-appearing lymph nodes on the slide. At low power, this node (the large, round one in the lower center) shows a diffuse and monotonous dark purple appearance, indicating a dense cell population has replaced the normal architecture of follicles and sinuses. This is an abnormal finding. The key question is the nature of this effacement: is it due to metastatic carcinoma, a lymphoma, or an unusual reactive process? Zooming in is necessary to examine the cellular details (cytology) and architectural patterns at high magnification to make this distinction and determine if the node is positive for metastasis. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, I would systematically examine each potential lymph node. The area indicated by the green box is a large, well-circumscribed, and highly cellular lymph node located in the lower-center of the image. I would zoom into this area to assess the lymph node's architecture at high magnification. The goal is to look for any foreign cell populations, such as clusters of atypical epithelial cells (adenocarcinoma), which would appear as irregular nests or glands, often with a different staining pattern (more eosinophilic cytoplasm) than the surrounding lymphocytes. Any architectural effacement or distortion is a key feature to investigate. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my task is to examine every single lymph node for evidence of metastasis, no matter how small. I am systematically reviewing each tissue fragment. The green box is placed on a lymph node that, even at low power, shows an architectural abnormality. There appears to be a focal, slightly paler (more eosinophilic) area within the dense lymphoid tissue, particularly near the subcapsular region. This subtle change in color and texture is suspicious for a small metastatic deposit. I would zoom into this specific interface between the suspicious area and the normal lymphoid tissue to assess the cytology and confirm if atypical, non-lymphoid cells are present. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my primary task here is to screen every lymph node for evidence of metastasis. The green box is placed over one of the lymph nodes (the third one from the top in the right column). It is standard practice to systematically examine each lymph node at higher magnification to look for tumor cells, which can be subtle. This particular node shows some architectural variation at low power, with mottling of the usual dense blue appearance, prompting a closer look to rule out metastatic infiltration within the sinuses. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my primary goal for this case is to identify any lymph node metastasis, which is a critical factor in determining the patient's prognosis and treatment plan. I would systematically examine every piece of tissue that appears to be a lymph node. The area indicated by the green box is one of these candidate lymph nodes. It appears dark and densely cellular from this low magnification, which could be due to a reactive process or, more importantly, replacement by metastatic tumor. Therefore, it requires high-magnification examination to determine its status. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I would zoom into this area, which is at the periphery of a lymph node in the upper right quadrant, for a critical reason: to assess for extranodal extension (ENE). This is the point where the lymph node capsule interfaces with the surrounding perinodal adipose tissue (fat). Looking closely at this junction is essential to determine if the metastatic tumor is confined within the lymph node or if it has breached the capsule and is invading the adjacent fat. The presence of ENE is a significant adverse prognostic factor and must be carefully evaluated and reported. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my goal is to assess each lymph node for the presence of metastasis. I would systematically examine every piece of tissue. The selected area is one of the lymph nodes. Its border with the surrounding fatty tissue appears somewhat irregular, and the lymphoid tissue itself has a mottled appearance with a mix of dark purple and lighter pink areas. This heterogeneity raises suspicion for infiltration by tumor cells, making it a crucial area to examine at high magnification to look for atypical cells and assess for extranodal extension. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, every lymph node on the slide must be systematically examined at higher magnification to look for metastatic cancer cells. This area, highlighted by the green box, is one of the lymph nodes in the upper-central region of the slide. I am zooming in on it as part of my routine, methodical screening process to ensure no evidence of metastasis, including small deposits (micrometastases or isolated tumor cells), is missed. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, I see the wall of a large vein, characterized by thick bundles of smooth muscle and fibrous tissue (pink). Infiltrating this vessel wall are multiple irregular, back-to-back malignant glands, which are diagnostic of adenocarcinoma. The glandular cells show significant atypia. The lumen of the vessel (top of the image) contains extensive necrotic debris. My impression is that this is a clear-cut case of extramural venous invasion (EMVI), a poor prognostic factor.
This is ROI 2 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view shows a lymph node surrounded by perinodal adipose tissue. The lymph node architecture appears preserved, with a dense population of small, round lymphocytes with dark nuclei and scant cytoplasm. I can discern follicular structures. There are no definitive clusters of atypical epithelial cells, glandular formations, or large cells with prominent nucleoli and eosinophilic cytoplasm that would be indicative of metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression is that this is a benign, reactive lymph node, negative for malignancy.
This is ROI 3 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-magnification view, the lymph node architecture is effaced by a dense infiltrate of small, dark lymphocytes. However, scattered throughout this lymphoid stroma, there are clearly identifiable, back-to-back and irregularly shaped glands. The cells lining these glands are atypical; they have enlarged, pleomorphic, and hyperchromatic nuclei with eosinophilic cytoplasm. These features are characteristic of metastatic adenocarcinoma. Therefore, my impression is that this is a positive lymph node containing metastatic colorectal adenocarcinoma.
This is ROI 4 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, I see a diffuse sheet of small, mature-looking lymphocytes with round nuclei and scant cytoplasm. The normal lymph node architecture is completely effaced. A prominent feature is the presence of numerous small blood vessels with plump endothelial cells (high endothelial venules or HEVs) scattered throughout the lymphoid infiltrate. I do not see any glandular structures, nests of atypical epithelial cells, or features of adenocarcinoma that would indicate metastasis from a colorectal primary. The impression is that this lymph node is involved by a low-grade B-cell lymphoproliferative disorder, such as small lymphocytic lymphoma/chronic lymphocytic leukemia (SLL/CLL). This appears to be an incidental finding unrelated to the colorectal cancer. For the purpose of staging the colon cancer, this node would be classified as negative for metastasis.
This is ROI 5 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, the normal architecture of the lymph node is altered. There is a dense background of small, mature-appearing lymphocytes. However, this lymphoid tissue is intersected by prominent, irregular, and branching bands of eosinophilic, spindle-cell-rich stroma (fibrosis/sclerosis). I do not see definitive nests of malignant glandular cells or single atypical epithelial cells. The appearance is suggestive of significant stromal sclerosis or fibrosis within the lymph node. While this can be a reactive change, it can also be associated with a treated metastasis (stromal response to tumor). However, based on this field alone, there are no unequivocal features of metastatic carcinoma. My impression is reactive stromal fibrosis, but I would carefully examine the rest of the node and other nodes for any identifiable tumor cells.
This is ROI 6 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, there is a clear demarcation between two cell populations. The majority of the field (upper part) consists of dense, small, dark-staining lymphocytes, which are native to the lymph node. In the lower left, there is a distinct, irregularly shaped nest of atypical cells. These cells are larger, have more abundant eosinophilic (pink) cytoplasm, and larger, more vesicular nuclei than the surrounding lymphocytes. They are clustered together in a cohesive manner, which is characteristic of epithelial cells. This is a classic presentation of metastatic adenocarcinoma infiltrating the subcapsular sinus and parenchyma of a lymph node. My impression is definitive: this is a positive lymph node containing metastatic carcinoma.
This is ROI 7 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-magnification view, I see the parenchyma of a lymph node. The tissue is composed predominantly of a dense population of small, round, dark-staining cells, which are lymphocytes. There are also dilated lymphatic sinuses filled with red blood cells (hemorrhage) and some larger cells with more abundant eosinophilic (pink) cytoplasm, consistent with sinus histiocytes. I do not see any definitive nests or glands of atypical epithelial cells with large, irregular nuclei that would be characteristic of metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression of this specific field of view is a reactive lymph node with sinus histiocytosis and hemorrhage, which are benign changes. The node appears negative for malignancy in this area.
This is ROI 8 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see the edge of a lymph node adjacent to perinodal adipose tissue. The normal architecture of the lymph node (i.e., distinct cortex, paracortex, and medulla with germinal centers and sinuses) appears to be effaced and replaced by a dense, diffuse sheet of small, dark, round cells (lymphocytes). While the architecture is abnormal, I do not see the classic features of metastatic colorectal adenocarcinoma in this specific field, such as atypical glandular structures, large pleomorphic cells with prominent nucleoli, or dirty necrosis. My impression is that this likely represents a reactive lymph node with significant sinus histiocytosis or follicular hyperplasia, or possibly an incidental finding of a low-grade lymphoma (like SLL/CLL). To make a definitive diagnosis, I would need to carefully scan the entire lymph node to rule out any small focus of metastatic carcinoma.
This is ROI 9 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-magnification view, I see the edge of a lymph node that is extensively infiltrated by metastatic carcinoma, represented by the dense sheet of dark, atypical cells on the left. The tumor is seen breaking through the pink, fibrous lymph node capsule and infiltrating into the surrounding adipose tissue on the right. There are clear, irregular nests and clusters of malignant cells scattered among the fat cells. My definitive impression is a metastatic adenocarcinoma in a lymph node with clear evidence of extranodal extension.
This is ROI 10 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, I can clearly see lymph node parenchyma being infiltrated by malignant cells. There are sheets of native small, dark lymphocytes. Interspersed and disrupting this architecture are nests, cords, and poorly-formed glands of atypical epithelial cells. These malignant cells are larger than the surrounding lymphocytes, have more abundant eosinophilic (pink) cytoplasm, and pleomorphic, hyperchromatic nuclei. They are seen infiltrating both the lymphoid tissue and the surrounding fibro-adipose tissue. My impression is definitive for metastatic adenocarcinoma within this lymph node.
This is ROI 11 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see a lymph node with a well-preserved architecture. There are multiple lymphoid follicles, some containing paler-staining germinal centers, set within a background of darker-staining lymphocytes. This pattern is indicative of follicular hyperplasia, a benign reactive change. I do not see any clusters of atypical cells, abnormal glandular structures, or single infiltrating malignant cells that would be characteristic of metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression is that this is a reactive lymph node, negative for malignancy (N0).
